The source data was developed by adding to the MeGIS Level 5 HUC 10 database, thus extending the spatial depiction of Watershed boundary regions to describe occupation status of salmon in Maine.</abstract>    <purpose>WATERSHED boundaries provide a standard level of detail that is an acceptable unit to describe salmon habitat, and the HUC 10s are nationally recognized by the USGS to spatially relate any dataset that contains these codes.</purpose>    <langdata Sync="TRUE">en</langdata></descript>   <timeperd>    <timeinfo> However, this coverage should not be redistributed without permission from the data source and/or originator. Please see Maine Office of Geographic Information Systems (MEGIS) License Agreement at http://megis.maine.gov/ . Any secondary distribution must have this documentation appended.</accconst>   <useconst> This data set is to be used as a primary reference source.  This is public information and may be interpreted by organizations, agencies, units of government, or others based upon needs; however, each is responsible for the appropriate application.  Federal, state, or local regulatory bodies are not to reassign to the Natural Resources Conservation Service any authority for the decisions that they make based upon these data.  Photographic or digital enlargement of these maps to scales greater than that at which they were originally delineated can cause misrepresentation of the data.  If enlarged, the maps will not include the fine detail that would be appropriate for mapping at the larger scale.  Digital data files are periodically updated.  Files are dated, and users are responsible for obtaining the latest version of the data. </useconst>   <ptcontac>    <cntinfo>     <cntpos>Fisheries Biologist</cntpos>     <cntaddr>      <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype>      <address>17 Godfrey Drive - Suite 1</address>      <city>Orono</city>      <state>ME</state>      <postal>04473</postal>      <country>USA</country>     </cntaddr>     <cntvoice>(207) 866 7320</cntvoice>     <cntfax>(207) 866-7342</cntfax>     <cntemail>dan.kircheis@noaa.gov</cntemail> SMMS_Contact_Email_Hyperlinked:  false <cntperp><cntper>Dan Kircheis</cntper><cntorg>NOAA Fisheries Maine Field Station</cntorg></cntperp></cntinfo>   </ptcontac>   <datacred>The U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service, should be acknowledged as the data source in products derived from these data.  Also, NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) should be acknowledged as the data source for Critical Habitat information about Atlantic salmon.</datacred>   <native Sync="TRUE">Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.5.1450</native> SMMS_Type:  1 SMMS_Dataset_Capture_Browse:  false SMMS_Dataset: SMMS_DatasetLayer: SMMS_DatasetLayer_Order:  0 SMMS_DatasetLayer_Type:  1 SMMS_DatasetLayer_Location:  \\\\bis-isa1AS2GIS\\HOME11\\crypt83\\state SMMS_DatasetLayer_Name:  WBDME6_A_Area SMMS_DatasetLayer_LabelVisible:  0 SMMS_DatasetLayer_Style1:  0 SMMS_DatasetLayer_Color:  -2 SMMS_DatasetLayer_Weight:  0 SMMS_DatasetLayer: SMMS_DatasetLayer_Order:  1 SMMS_DatasetLayer_Type:  0 SMMS_DatasetLayer_LabelVisible:  0 SMMS_DatasetLayer_Style1:  0 SMMS_DatasetLayer_Color:  0 SMMS_DatasetLayer_Weight:  0 <natvform Sync="TRUE">Shapefile</natvform></idinfo>  <dataqual>   <attracc>    <attraccr>Polygon identifiers were manually checked against other base maps and tables using the attribute file.  Extensive verification of attributes and spatial integrity was performed onscreen on a digital workstation using vendor software.</attraccr>   </attracc>   <logic>Certain node/geometry and topology (GT) polygon/chain relationships are collected or generated to satisfy topological requirements.  (The GT-polygon corresponds to a hydrologic unit or a portion of a hydrologic unit at the edge of a quadrangle sheet.)  Some of these requirements include: chains must begin and end at nodes, left and right GT-polygons are defined for each chain element and are consistent throughout, and the chains representing the limits of the file are free of gaps.  The tests of logical consistency are performed using vendor software.  All internal polygons are tested for closure with vendor software.  All data are checked for common boundary lines (i.e., adjacent polygons with the same label).  Polygons that carry over into other states are exactly edge matched.  Subwatershed polygons are named for the most downstream hydrographic feature. Hydrologic Unit Areas at Levels 6 (12-digit), 5 (10 digit), 4 (8-digit), 3 (6-digit), can be mapped from this dataset.</logic>   <complete> This revision of the Watershed Boundary Database is known as Version 2.1.  The attributes Hu_12_mod, Hu_12_type, Hu_10_mod, and Hu_10_type are required data elements as per the current national digitizing standard, but are incomplete as of this revision.  The large polygons along the Canadian border do not currently meet the size standard for either Level 6 or Level 5 polygons.  Detail will be added as data for watershed areas on the Canadian side are acquired or developed.  Coastal polygons currently do not include ocean waters between the coastline and the three-mile territorial limit.  Standards for delineation of coastal polygons as well as a methodology to support them are under development.  Details, particularly combining multiple island areas into single polygons, will be added when the standard has been formalized. </complete>   <posacc>    <horizpa>     <horizpar> The accuracy of these maps is generally based upon the contour information of corresponding hardcopy USGS 7.5 minute series topographic quadrangles and their derivative DRGs. Accuracy of these source data meets National Map Accuracy Standard for 1:24000 scale data, or a minimum of +/- 12 meters of ground location. The differences in positional accuracy between the hydrologic unit area boundaries and their digitized map locations are unknown.  Hydrologic unit area boundaries generally were digitized within 0.01 inches of their locations on the digitizing source.  Edge match locations are exact because the data were extracted from a New England-based hydrologic unit area data set that had been electronically edge-matched. </horizpar>    </horizpa>   </posacc>   <lineage>    <srcinfo>     <srccite>      <citeinfo>       <origin>Maine Office of Geographic Information Systems (MEGIS)</origin>       <pubdate>19940101</pubdate>       <pubtime>Unknown</pubtime>       <title>medrdvd</title>       <geoform>vector digital data</geoform>       <serinfo>        <sername>Maine GIS Data Catalog; Standard 7.5x7.5 minute quadrangles cover geographic areas of 49 to 71 square miles. 1 inch at map scale represents 2000 feet.</othercit>       <onlink>http://mapping.usgs.gov/mac/maplists/howtoselectmaps.html</onlink> SMMS_Citation_Linkages_Hyperlinked:  false SMMS_Citation_Source_Scale:  24000 SMMS_Citation_Source_Media:  stable-base material (mylar) SMMS_Citation_Source_Time_Period: SMMS_Citation_Source_Currentness:  publication date </citeinfo>     </srccite>     <srcscale>24000</srcscale>     <typesrc>stable-base material (mylar)</typesrc>     <srctime>      <timeinfo>       <rngdates>        <begdate>19480101</begdate>        <begtime>Unknown</begtime>        <enddate>Present</enddate>        <endtime>Unknown</endtime>       </rngdates>      </timeinfo>      <srccurr>publication date</srccurr>     </srctime>     <srccitea>24k</srccitea>    </srcinfo>    <procstep>     <procdesc>The source data for WBDME6_A was developed by delineating boundary lines on a USGS base of 1:24000 scale topographic quadrangles prior to digitization. Digital Raster Graphic (DRGs) images of the 1:24000 quadrangles are used to edit the data set. SUBWATERSHED polygons were delineated on mylar and attributed with hydrologic unit area (HUA) code and alphanumeric name. Source polygons were digitally attributed in ArcEdit by NRCS and "dissolved" on the HUC_12 attribute to produce the current Level 6 (12-digit) SUBWATERSHED vector coverage.</procdesc>     <srcused>medrdvd</srcused>     <srcused>drg</srcused>     <srcused>24k</srcused>     <procdate>199806</procdate>     <proccont>      <cntinfo>       <cntorgp>        <cntorg>(NRCSME) USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service</cntorg>        <cntper>Resources Inventory/Geographic Information Specialist</cntper>       </cntorgp>       <cntpos>Resources Inventory/Geographic Information Specialist</cntpos>       <cntaddr>        <addrtype>mailing and physical address</addrtype>        <address>967 Illinois Avenue Suite 3</address>        <city>Bangor</city>        <state>ME</state>        <postal>04401</postal>        <country>USA</country>       </cntaddr>       <cntvoice>(207) 990 9100-3</cntvoice>       <cntfax>(207) 990-9599</cntfax>       <cntemail>ray.voyer@me.usda.gov</cntemail>       <hours>Monday through Friday 0800 - 1630 EST</hours> SMMS_Contact_Email_Hyperlinked:  false </cntinfo>     </proccont>     <srcused>wbdme6_a</srcused></procstep>    <procstep>     <procdesc>Dataset copied.</procdesc>    </procstep>    <procstep>     <procdesc> Two offensive name references corrected (MRS1section1101) Squa Pan Stream to Squapan Stream and Squa or Squaw Bay to Moose Bay. River Basin including part of Merrymeeting Bay. 010400 The Androscoggin River Basin including part of Merrymeeting Bay 010500 The Eastern Maine Coastal drainage and associated waters from the Sync="TRUE">19</attwidth><atnumdec Sync="TRUE">11</atnumdec></attr></detailed>   <overview>    <eaover> Hydrologic unit delineations are closed polygons that encompass all area draining toward the lowest point (called outlet) in the polygon.  The nominal sizes for the different hydrologic unit levels are: 1) Basin ( ) 2) Subbasin ( >250,000 acres), 3) Watershed (40,000 to 250,000 acres), and 4) Subwatersheds (3,000-acre minumum, generally 10,000 to 40,000 acres).   Some polygons, because of the size criteria, may not be headwater polygons, but reach polygons in the drainage chain.  A unique code is used to identify each hydrologic unit.  The hydrologic unit area coding system is hierarchical, starting with the USGS 6-digit Basin (formerly called Accounting Unit) code.  The Subbasin (7th and 8th digits) code is appended to the parental Basin code, the Watershed (9th and 10th digits) code is appended to the parental Subbasin code.  Likewise, the Subwatershed (11th and 12th digits) code is appended to the parental Watershed code.  The concatenation of the four codes provides the unique identifier at the Subwatershed level.  In coastal areas multiple polygons may have the same Subwatershed code, reflecting the existence of islands or non-contiguous contributing areas along the shoreline.  This situation will be addressed after a standard and methodology are finalized for coastal areas. </eaover>    <eadetcit>Federal Geographic Data Committee.  2001.  Federal Standards for Delineation of Hydrologic Unit Boundaries.  June 12, 2001. Draft with e-mailed amendments to certain polygon and arc attribute structures.</eadetcit>   </overview>  </eainfo>  <distinfo>   <distrib>    <cntinfo>     <cntorgp>      <cntorg>(MEGIS) Maine Office of Geographic Information Systems</cntorg>     </cntorgp>     <cntaddr>      <addrtype>mailing address</addrtype>      <address>State House Station 145</address>      <city>Augusta</city>      <state>ME</state>      <postal>04333-0145</postal>      <country>USA</country>     </cntaddr>     <cntvoice>(207) 287-6144</cntvoice>     <cntfax>(207) 287-4563</cntfax>     <hours>Monday through Friday 0800 - 1700 EST</hours> SMMS_Contact_Email_Hyperlinked:  false </cntinfo>   </distrib>   <resdesc>Downloadable Data from MEGIS for Level 5 HUC 10 Watershed boundaries.  Atlantic salmon critical habitat information must be requested from Dan Kircheis at NOAA Fisheries Maine Field Station.</resdesc>   <distliab>Users must assume responsibility to determine the usability of this data for their purposes. Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the Maine Office of Geographic Information Systems, no warranty expressed or implied is made by MEGIS regarding the utility of the data on any other system, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Neither the Maine Office of Geographic Information Systems, nor any of its contributors, is liable for misuse of the data, for damage, for transmission of viruses, or for computer contamination through the distribution of these data sets.</distliab>   <stdorder>    <digform>     <digtinfo>      <formname>ARCE</formname>      <formvern>ARC Version 9.x</formvern>      <formspec>ARC/INFO Export Format for MEGIS Watersheds</formspec>      <formcont>An Arc/Info export file is an interchange format used to transfer spatial data, INFO data files, and other ESRI ARC/INFO files between various machine types.  Export files have the suffix .e00 and contain, in fixed-length ASCII format, all spatial information available for each feature. The command IMPORT is available in A/I to convert the export file to original format, i.e. coverage, grid, or other spatial data file.  Import will add a spatial data file and a related INFO file to a machine directory. ESRI's ArcView is packaged with an import utility called IMPORT71 for the same export file conversion. The utility is also available through the FREE software link on the Maine GIS Internet Data Catalog under "CDProducts" at http://megis.maine.gov/catalog/ or from ESRI at http://www.esri.com/. CARE MUST BE TAKEN after import, not to separate the spatial information from its related INFO file. Since export files are in ASCII format make sure any file transfer method like FTP is executed under ASCII mode. Binary transfer may not work correctly.</formcont>      <asciistr>       <casesens>false</casesens>      </asciistr>      <transize Sync="TRUE">0.000</transize><dssize Sync="TRUE">0.000</dssize></digtinfo>    </digform>    <digform>     <digtinfo>      <formname>ESRI Shapefile</formname>      <formvern>ARC Version 9.x</formvern>      <formspec>ArcView Shapefile Format for MEGIS Watersheds</formspec>      <formcont>MEGIS has made some data, in the Internet Data Catalog, available in ESRI's ArcView shapefile format. This additional format is available for E911RDS and WETCHAR data under the TOWNS tab.  A shapefile is a simple non-topological format that stores the geometry and attribute information for a set of geographic features as a set of vector (point, line, polygon) coordinates. Shapefiles draw quickly and directly in ArcView; you can create your own data using the shapefile format; an existing ARC/INFO coverage can be converted to a shapefile; other spatial data formats can be converted to shapefiles. Three files are created for each shapefile: .shp stores the feature geometry (shape and location information); .shx stores the index of the feature geometry; .dbf a dBASE (TM) file stores the attribute information for the features. Other index files may be created to help speed analysis and query: these file formats are .sbn  .sbx  .ain .aix .fbn and .fbx. In addition you may find projection .prj, and metadata .xml, files associated with shapefiles. CAUTION: When you edit an existing theme or shapefile you are creating a new dataset or at least a new version of a dataset; give the dataset a new name or a version identifier to reflect your edits. Be prepared to fully document your sources and to both quantify and qualify the edits you make in order  to facilitate coordination with other data sources. PLEASE NOTE: conversion to shapefile format changes some characters ( # - .) to underscores; item names over 10 characters are truncated. An effort will be made over time to consider these limitations in item names, and to eliminate the use of these characters in Maine GIS data development. It should not be assumed that a conversion from shapefile back to coverage would produce the same data file as found in the original coverage format. The results of such a conversion are greatly improved by the use of PRECISION setting DOUBLE, DOUBLE and careful management of tolerances.</formcont>      <asciistr>       <casesens>false</casesens>      </asciistr>      <transize Sync="TRUE">0.000</transize><dssize Sync="TRUE">0.000</dssize></digtinfo>     <digtopt>      <onlinopt>       <computer>        <networka>         <networkr>http://megis.maine.gov/catalog/</networkr> SMMS_Hyperlinked:  -1 </networka>       </computer>       <accinstr>Anyone with an Internet browser can download these data from the Maine GIS Internet Data Catalog. All data available from this website is in .zip compressed format. WinZip is a Windows based, PKZip-compatible compression utility. You will need a program like this to extract the data. A link to a trial copy WinZip software is available at http://megis.maine.gov/software.asp. If you are not already a GIS user, a link to free software for import and viewing of these files, Import71 and ArcExplorer from Environmental Systems Research Institute, Inc. (ESRI), is available at http://megis.maine.gov/software.asp.</accinstr>      </onlinopt> SMMS_Distribution_Type:  1 </digtopt>     <digtopt>      <onlinopt>       <accinstr>Where file size and Internet access permit, data requests can be made available via File Transfer Protocol (FTP).</accinstr>      </onlinopt> SMMS_Distribution_Type:  1 </digtopt>    </digform>    <fees>Watershed data may be downloaded from Maine GIS Internet Data Catalog at no charge.  NMFS critical habitat data must be requested from NMFS.</fees>    <turnarnd>Watershed data is available for immediate download from the Maine GIS Internet Data Catalog.</turnarnd> SMMS_Distribution_Type:  1 <digform><digtinfo><formname>Personal Geodatabase</formname><formvern>ArcGIS 9.2 SP1</formvern><transize>55.3</transize><dssize>55.3</dssize><formspec>Personal ATS Management Geodatabase</formspec><formcont>Relates ATS Habitat Summary, Critical Habitat Occupation, and Stocking Management</formcont></digtinfo><digtopt><onlinopt/><offoptn><offmedia>CD-ROM</offmedia></offoptn></digtopt></digform></stdorder>   <custom>MEGIS provides technical support for Maine GIS data, estimates on custom mapping, and consultation on data and application development, as time permits.
